overview.overview:
Appeals by Milton Park group companies against closure notices denying corporation tax deductions for amortisation of purchased goodwill and related group relief. The Tribunal had to decide whether MPHL’s accounts were prepared in accordance with GAAP such that goodwill could properly be recognised. The parties agreed valuation consequences depending on whether goodwill recognition was GAAP-compliant. The Tribunal addressed a preliminary application to admit late witness statements (admitted), confirmed the burden of proof lies on the Appellants, and heard extensive factual and expert accounting evidence concerning the recognition of goodwill linked to care home businesses operated through partnerships and companies connected to MM and EM.
This extract chronicles the formation and operation of the Milton Park Partnership (MPP), its admission of corporate partners BHL and BCSL to provide central services and staffing (including a profit-share for BCSL equal to staffing costs plus a 35% mark-up), the opening and operation of Milton Park Hospital, and a 2007 restructuring plan to incorporate the business under Section 162 TCGA 1992 into MPHL and MPL while preserving VAT efficiency and small-company disclosure status. It also records withdrawal of BHL and BCSL from MPP in late 2007 and continued staffing arrangements via a proposed Milton Care Partnership.
This section details the restructuring of the Milton Park care home business around late 2007 to early 2008. BCSL and BHL ceased as partners in the Milton Park Partnership (becoming creditors), while a new corporate vehicle, MPHL, acquired the partnership’s assets and liabilities as a going concern. MPL was tasked with day-to-day management for MPHL. A new partnership, Milton Care Partnership (MCP), was formed between MPL and SM from 1 January 2008, with SM as Managing Partner and goodwill owned by MPHL. BCSL joined MCP on 3 January 2008 to supply employees. Payment arrangements for BCSL and BHL in the interim were not formalized, and no separate fee was paid to BCSL between its MPP exit and MCP admission.
Chronological account of Milton Care Partnership developments: BCSL and BHL admitted as partners to supply staffing/administrative services on profit-share terms; goodwill retained by MPHL with partners’ rights limited for BCSL/BHL; regulatory scrutiny in 2008–2010 with BHL as registered person/owner for regulatory purposes; 2009 governance shift with MPHL assuming MPL’s role; 2009 property transfers citing FA 2003 Sch 15 Pt 3; 2013 partners’ resolution tied to refinancing and extension of BCSL arrangements; and 2015 sale of MPHL to Tracscare. Operationally, properties initially owned by MM/EM (no rent), staffing by BCSL/BHL, and Brookdale branding used.
This section describes operational, regulatory, and financial aspects of the Milton Park Hospital business, including BHL’s centralised regulatory role, use of the Brookdale branding, staffing by BCSL and BHL, and property transfers to MPHL. It details MPHL’s and MPL’s financial reporting, notably substantial goodwill recognition, amortisation and impairment, and minimal turnover, as well as a 2015 share sale to Tracscare. It sets out the tax positions taken by MPHL (goodwill deductions) and MPL (group relief claim) and HMRC’s enquiries and closure notices in 2019 disallowing goodwill amortisation and reducing MPL’s group relief, with those conclusions upheld on review.
Expert evidence (Dr Alford) addresses GAAP treatment of goodwill arising from MPHL’s 2009 transaction, contrasting valuations (£174.59m vs £51.94m) and their impact on amortisation and GAAP compliance through 2017. A hypothetical regulatory requirement related to Care Standards Act registration is considered for its effect on whether MPHL (or MCP) acquired and operated the business. The Tribunal also sets out undisputed legislation governing tax treatment of goodwill under FA 2002 Sch 29 and CTA 2009 Part 8 and lists relevant FRSs.
HMRC disallowed goodwill amortisation claimed by MPHL across multiple accounting periods (2008–2017) and adjusted MPL’s 2009 group relief position, resulting in tax assessments. These amendments were upheld on review. The dispute involves whether MPHL acquired a business for GAAP purposes and whether recognising and continuing to amortise goodwill in MPHL’s accounts was appropriate, including any derecognition upon subsequent operation through MPL. Competing expert evidence addresses the application of UK GAAP (FRS 6, FRS 5, FRS 10) and the allocation of risks, rewards, and control over the business operations.
Dispute about whether MPHL correctly recognised purchased goodwill under UK GAAP following its December 2007 acquisition of the MPP care home business and whether later delegation of operations to MPL and formation of MCP required derecognition. Appellants say control, risks, and rewards remained with MPHL; HMRC says MCP operated the business and MPHL lacked operational control, so goodwill was not recognisable or should have been derecognised/valued lower.
The tribunal considers whether transactions involving MPHL and MPP constituted a business combination under FRS 6 by assessing whether MPHL obtained control over MPP’s net assets and operations. The Appellants’ expert relied on IFRS 3/FRED 36 to define “business,” but the tribunal agrees with HMRC that UK GAAP (FRSSE, FRS 5, FRS 6) governs and provides adequate definitions, rendering reliance on IFRS unnecessary. Control over net assets appears satisfied (subject to substance‑over‑form), and the tribunal emphasises analysing the series of transactions as a whole to identify where risks and rewards reside to determine control over operations.
Dispute over whether, in substance and for GAAP purposes, the care home business and its goodwill were transferred to the new partnership MCP or retained by MPHL. Applying FRS 5.14’s substance-over-form approach to a pre-ordained series of transactions, the Tribunal assessed who controlled the business and bore its risks and rewards. The Tribunal found that MCP, led by its Managing Partner SM, operated and controlled the business, with MCP’s accounts recording all turnover and expenses, and that MPHL did not retain control or goodwill for accounting recognition.
Whether MCP operated the care home business (rather than merely managing it for MPHL) and whether MPL acted as MPHL’s agent. The tribunal relied on MCP’s accounting for all turnover and costs as evidencing control under accounting principles (SoP 2.6). Branding/registration under BHL were not determinative; decisive were MCP’s partnership composition and control of staff. The asserted agency of MPL for MPHL was undermined by lack of an explicit agency appointment by MPHL and absence of remuneration, applying agency law principles.
The Tribunal considered whether MPHL retained significant benefits/risks and control over the business’s profits and sale proceeds under FRS 5 after forming MCP. Based on the MCP Deed and evidence of how profits were determined, it found control lay with SM as Managing Partner, not MPHL; therefore, FRS 5.25 did not support recognising or continuing to recognise goodwill in MPHL’s accounts, and MPHL did not control proceeds of any future sale or profits arising from income.
The Tribunal considered whether MPL acted as agent for MPHL and whether MPHL retained the principal risks and rewards of the care home business under GAAP (FRS 5). HMRC argued there was no agency and that MPHL did not retain significant benefits/risks; the Appellants, via expert PC, argued MPHL retained control over benefits and bore principal risks. The Tribunal agreed with HMRC, rejecting agency, finding operations passed to MCP, and holding MPHL’s retained rights were not significant in practice under FRS 5.25.
Dispute concerns whether MPHL retained control and the risks and rewards of a care home business for GAAP/FRS 5 purposes, focusing on who controlled profit allocation, access to sale proceeds, bearing of losses, and treatment of goodwill under the MCP Deed and admission deeds.
Issue on whether references to “goodwill” in the MCP Deed mean legal goodwill and whether such goodwill (and proceeds attributable to it) could belong to MPHL rather than the MCP partnership. The tribunal held that legal goodwill is inseparable from the business and thus belongs to the partnership (MCP), not MPHL; also, no evidence was adduced as to the monetary value of any legal goodwill.
The case concerns whether MPHL, following the formation of the MCP partnership to operate the Milton Park care home business, controlled the business such that it could recognise purchased goodwill under UK GAAP. The Tribunal rejected the Appellants’ reliance on Lindley & Banks paragraph 10-100 to allocate goodwill outside the partnership and found MPHL lacked control under FRS 5.8; control resided with MCP and its Managing Partner. Appeals dismissed.
Issue: whether MPHL, a non-partner, owned the partnership’s legal goodwill or had an entitlement to sale proceeds under the MCP Deed of Partnership. Held: TTYP is persuasive on the inseparability of goodwill from the business; case law does not support ownership of partnership goodwill by a non-partner in these circumstances. On construction, clause 9.1 does not confer an entitlement to sale proceeds and clause 14.2.1 creates only a debt obligation on dissolution; the Deed’s amendability further undermines any claimed proprietary entitlement. The presumption that goodwill is a partnership asset is not rebutted on these facts.

judges_comments.dicta:
- Lateness of evidence, without more, was not a compelling reason to refuse admission where the evidence was relevant; any issue goes to weight.
- The burden of proof is on the Appellants to show the closure notice conclusions are wrong on the balance of probabilities.
- The Tribunal need not address every point in submissions; it is sufficient to consider key issues and material referred to.
- Both GAAP experts were qualified to give expert evidence.
The Tribunal noted the relevant legislation governing goodwill taxation was undisputed and that FA 2002 Sch 29 and CTA 2009 Part 8 are materially to the same effect; therefore, FA 2002 provisions were cited with cross-references to CTA 2009.
UK GAAP governs: where UK standards (FRSSE, FRS 5, FRS 6) address the issue, international standards like IFRS 3 and FRED 36 are advisory and should not displace extant UK standards, particularly when not in force and when they exclude common‑control combinations. FRS 6 focuses on whether control over net assets and operations is obtained; importing a separate definition of “business” is unnecessary. Substance over form requires viewing a series of transactions as a whole and giving greater weight to commercially effective aspects; control is linked to access to benefits and bearing associated risks.
A group or series of transactions designed to achieve an overall commercial effect should be viewed as a whole (FRS 5.14). Legal declarations of ownership cannot override the objective assessment of control required under GAAP. The Tribunal must assess who had the ability to direct the financial and operating policies of the business with a view to obtaining economic benefits; on the evidence, that power rested with MCP and its Managing Partner, SM.
MCP’s recognition of all turnover and costs for the care home evidences that it, not MPHL, controlled the business. MPHL’s failure to record any income or expenditure associated with the business is inconsistent with SoP 2.6 and undermines the notion that MPHL presented a true and fair view. Ownership of trademarks and registration under the Care Standards Act 2000 by BHL is not determinative of who operated the care home. Determinative is that BHL and BCSL were partners in MCP and MCP, through SM, controlled staff and administrative services. Minutes of MPHL did not record any agency appointment of MPL; absent express or implied assent, agency is not established by assertions in MPL’s minutes.
Significance under FRS 5.25 is assessed by reference to benefits and risks likely to occur in practice; contingent, discretionary, or practically unenforceable rights are not significant. Ownership of real property does not equate to control of the business where the property is not a partnership asset and can be replaced. Control over profit allocation and access to sale proceeds vested in the MCP Managing Partner under the Deed; minutes do not show MM exercising decision-making authority. Informal or undocumented familial understandings cannot displace the objective legal and accounting analysis under GAAP; even if MM exercised de facto control, that would be his personal control, not control by MPHL.
The absence of any remuneration for MPL, lack of evident benefit to MPHL, absence of limitations on MPL’s discretion, and the accounting records all point away from an agency relationship. Even if MPL were acting as an agent, that would not establish that MPHL had control for GAAP purposes; control under FRS 5.8 requires the ability to direct the financial and operating policies with a view to obtaining economic benefits. Rights must be significant in practice under FRS 5.25; theoretical or contingent rights, or rights subject to others’ discretion (e.g., the Managing Partner), do not suffice.
Control for GAAP purposes depends on who has the authority to determine the distribution of future economic benefits, not on how profits were actually distributed. The MCP Deed vested profit-allocation and operational control in the Managing Partner (SM), not MPHL. Ownership of real property used by the partnership does not make it partnership property; losses are borne by partners. Clauses addressing goodwill concern legal goodwill and do not establish GAAP control or ownership of accounting goodwill.
- Legal goodwill is inseparable from the business out of which it arises; it cannot subsist independently and attaches to the business rather than an individual proprietor. - Clause 9.1’s “goodwill of the Partnership” necessarily refers to legal goodwill of the partnership business carried on in common; despite the deed stating otherwise, that legal goodwill belongs to the partnership (MCP), not MPHL. - Without evidence of monetary value for legal goodwill, any access to proceeds by reference to legal goodwill would be immaterial. - Authorities cited include Wedderburn v Wedderburn (No 4), IRC v Muller & Co’s Margarine Ltd, Star Industrial (noting Privy Council decisions are persuasive per Willers v Joyce), Geraghty v Minter, and TTYP.
- The presumption that goodwill belongs to the firm is rebuttable and depends on the partnership agreement and context; paragraph 10-100 of Lindley & Banks does not establish a rule permitting free allocation of goodwill to non-partners. - Clauses 9.1 and 14.2.1 of the MCP Deed did not give MPHL an entitlement to legal goodwill or confer a proprietary interest; clause 14.2.1 was silent and amendable by the Managing Partner. - A partner’s ability to withdraw or terminate arrangements does not amount to control; negative control (ability to shut down) is insufficient for accounting control. - Control in the relevant sense requires the ability to direct financial and operating policies to obtain economic benefits (FRS 5.8). - Any de facto control by MM personally or through other entities does not equate to control by MPHL given the legal structure of the MCP Deed.
Goodwill is personal property inseparable from and attached to the business, not to its proprietor, and may pass with the business, including to a licensee where expressly assigned. The natural and objective reading of clause 9.1 concerns ownership of legal goodwill as an asset, not entitlement to future sale proceeds. The term “accrue” in clause 14.2.1 signifies a right arising upon dissolution, consistent with a debt obligation rather than present proprietary entitlement. The general presumption that goodwill belongs to the firm may be rebutted, but that depends on construction of the partnership agreement and the factual matrix; it is relatively rare for goodwill to be owned outside the firm.
judges_comments.reasoning:
The Tribunal considered the Appellants’ application to admit late evidence against HMRC’s objections grounded in prior directions. It assessed relevance and the likelihood that the witnesses would refer to the statements during oral evidence, deciding to admit them and leaving questions of weight for submissions. It set the framework of the case by identifying the central GAAP issue and recording the parties’ agreements on valuation and tax consequences under alternative factual findings. It noted the burden of proof lies with the Appellants and confirmed reliance on the hearing transcript and extensive bundles. The Tribunal evaluated the witness and expert evidence, largely accepting JA’s and MM’s testimony (subject to exceptions), giving limited weight to LM’s hearsay evidence, and acknowledging both accounting experts’ qualifications before proceeding to findings of fact, including the formation and evolution of the Milton Park Partnership and subsequent business arrangements.
The Tribunal summarised statutory mechanics for bringing amortisation and impairment into account, determining tax written down value, and recognising amounts for accounting purposes (including adjustments where accounts are not GAAP-compliant), highlighting the linkage between GAAP and tax outcomes.
The tribunal assessed the hierarchy and applicability of accounting standards. It found that FRS 6 remained applicable at the relevant time and that FRSSE’s reference to “other accounting standards” pertains to UK standards and UITF abstracts, not IFRS. Since IFRS 3/FRED 36 exclude common‑control transactions and were not in force, they do not provide the operative framework. The tribunal then identified the correct FRS 6 test: whether MPHL obtained control over MPP’s net assets and operations. It reviewed authoritative definitions of control (FRS 5, SOP), distinguishing control from mere management and linking control to risks and rewards. On evidence, and subject to assumptions about the Transfer Agreement and witness statements, HMRC’s expert accepted MPHL gained control over net assets, which HMRC’s skeleton also acknowledged, but flagged the need for a substance‑over‑form analysis. The tribunal emphasised that the transactions must be evaluated as a whole to determine where risks and rewards truly lay, in order to assess control over operations.
The Tribunal considered the entire series of transactions and their commercial effect, as required by FRS 5.14 and FRSSE 2.2. It found that the transactions were pre-ordained to move the business from MPP to MCP and that, in practice, operational control and economic benefits passed to MCP and SM. The MCP Deed of Partnership stated the partners would carry on the business for their mutual benefit, and designated SM as Managing Partner with the final say on profit allocation. Cross-examination confirmed MCP operated the care home business for the partners, not as a manager for MPHL. MCP’s financial statements recorded all turnover and operating expenses; MPHL’s accounts showed no trading income and described it as a holding company. The Tribunal gave greater weight to these practical features than to Clause 9 reserving legal goodwill to MPHL, concluding that legal ownership statements do not determine control for accounting purposes. Therefore, under GAAP, MPHL did not control the business and could not recognise goodwill.
The tribunal applied substance-over-form, focusing on control of economic outcomes. MCP’s accounts included turnover and cost of sales consistent with operating a care home, and lacked any management-fee structure expected of a mere manager, aligning with SoP 2.6. Witness MM accepted the accounts gave a true and fair view. Expert EA’s interpretation under SoP 2.6 supported that MCP controlled profits, losses, assets, and liabilities. The tribunal rejected PC’s contrary view as inconsistent with the accounting evidence and MPHL’s omission to recognise any business income or costs. HMRC’s branding/registration points were discounted but the partnership structure and control over staff were decisive. On agency, comparison of MPL and MPHL minutes and the absence of remuneration, viewed through Bowstead & Reynolds’ definition of agency, indicated no express or implied agency.
The Tribunal analysed the MCP Deed of Partnership: Clause 8.2 vested profit-share determinations in the Managing Partner (SM) where partners disagreed, and Clause 14.2.3 tied any surplus/sale proceeds to the profit-sharing ratios immediately prior to dissolution—ratios which SM controlled. Evidence from MM and JA confirmed SM’s autonomy over profit allocation. The minutes corroborated that MCP, directed by SM, decided profit allocations; one outlier minute referencing MM’s direction did not override the Deed or demonstrate MM’s control. The rights asserted by MPHL (ability to terminate MPL’s role, real property ownership, purported goodwill entitlement) were either contingent, discretionary, or practically unenforceable and did not permit MPHL to direct MCP’s financial and operating policies, as required by FRS 5.8. PC’s expert opinion attributing profits to MPHL based on actual allocations was undermined by his concession that GAAP looks to who holds the authority to control future economic benefits; that authority lay with SM as Managing Partner. The alleged “informal family understanding” was unsupported by evidence and, even if it existed, could not displace the legal structure or confer control on MPHL under GAAP.
The Tribunal evaluated the documentary evidence (MPHL Board minutes of 31 December 2007), accounting treatments (MPL recognising turnover from MCP; MPHL recognising investment income only), and absence of any agency remuneration or constraints on MPL’s autonomy. It considered expert PC’s suggested accounting treatment under Application Note G of FRS 5 if an agency existed, finding this underscored the absence of an agency agreement. Oral testimony (MM and JA) indicated MPL was used as a subsidiary vehicle to channel profits to MPHL, not as agent, aligning with HMRC’s explanation. Applying FRS 5.8, the Tribunal concluded MPHL lacked the power to direct financial and operating policies of the business. On risks and rewards, the Tribunal weighed PC’s assertions about MPHL’s access to sale proceeds and residual profits against EA’s analysis of MCP’s governance: the Managing Partner (Sean McInerney) determined profit allocations, corporate partners had no voting rights, and MPL had full autonomy. Accepting HMRC’s submissions on FRS 5.25, the Tribunal determined the rights cited by the Appellants were not significant in practice, being contingent or subject to others’ discretion, and thus did not amount to MPHL retaining the principal risks and rewards.
The Tribunal relied on concessions by the Appellants’ expert (PC) that actual profit allocations are not determinative under GAAP and that the key is authority over future economic benefits. It examined the MCP Deed: Clause 8.2 grants SM final authority over profit shares; Clause 14 ties dissolution distributions to profit-sharing proportions and allocates legal goodwill proceeds to MPHL. Evidence showed SM, not MPHL, controlled access to sale proceeds. On risk-bearing, the Tribunal distinguished between partnership property and assets owned by a partner; despite MPHL owning the real property, it was not partnership property and thus losses would be borne by partners, not MPHL’s property assets. On goodwill, although documents state legal goodwill belongs to MPHL, this does not demonstrate retention of GAAP control. Accordingly, the Tribunal agreed with HMRC that MPHL did not retain control of the economic benefits and risks under GAAP.
The tribunal recorded the concession that the deed’s references to “goodwill” are to legal goodwill, not accounting goodwill. It rejected the appellants’ reliance on validation-oriented construction principles because those could not override the established legal nature of goodwill. The tribunal accepted HMRC’s submissions that MPHL did not bear the risks and rewards of the business through legal goodwill and that the appellants had provided no evidence of any monetary value for legal goodwill. Interpreting the MCP Deed, the tribunal found that “goodwill of the Partnership” refers to legal goodwill of the business carried on in common by the partners. Under the cited authorities, legal goodwill cannot be separated from the business to which it attaches and is owned by the partnership conducting the business. Therefore, any provision purporting to vest that legal goodwill in MPHL was ineffective as a matter of law. Accordingly, the tribunal agreed with HMRC and rejected the appellants’ submissions.
The Tribunal evaluated the partnership deed’s terms and the operational structure after formation of MCP. It found no express provision giving MPHL rights to goodwill proceeds or a proprietary interest, and noted dissolution distribution terms were amendable by the Managing Partner, undermining any claim that goodwill was held outside the firm. It considered termination arguments and found that partner withdrawal did not dissolve MCP (clause 12.2) and required surrender of partnership property (clause 16.2), so MPHL/MPL could not reclaim control; the business would continue with remaining partners. The Tribunal assessed the concept of control, rejecting the notion that withdrawing property use confers control and adopting FRS 5.8’s definition. It concluded that control of the business and its economic benefits sat with MCP, specifically its Managing Partner SM, not MPHL. Any alleged de facto control by MM could not override the governing legal instrument (the MCP Deed), which he had instructed, reviewed, and signed. Consequently, MPHL did not acquire a business for UK GAAP purposes and could not recognise purchased goodwill; HMRC’s alternative derecognition argument was moot.
The Tribunal considered TTYP and accepted its articulation of the inseparability principle. It compared the parties’ authorities and found none cited by the Appellants established that partnership goodwill can be owned by a non-partner where, at the relevant times, MPHL was not a partner. Interpreting clause 9.1, the Tribunal applied ordinary contractual construction and concluded the clause declares ownership but does not grant a right to sale proceeds; even if it did, the nature of such right (proprietary vs contractual) is ambiguous, particularly as MPHL was a volunteer without consideration. Turning to clause 14.2.1, the Tribunal read it as a dissolution distribution mechanism: proceeds are first used to pay debts/liabilities, with any sum from goodwill then accruing to MPHL. The word “accrue” indicates a contingent debt obligation arising on dissolution, not present ownership of proceeds. The Deed’s amendability by the Managing Partner (SM) further shows MPHL lacks secured access to proceeds. The Tribunal rejected the per incuriam challenge to High Court authorities referenced in Lindley & Banks, finding those authorities consistent with the rebuttable presumption that goodwill is a partnership asset. Applying that presumption and the Deed’s terms, the Tribunal concluded the presumption is not displaced in this case and goodwill was not intended to be a separate asset owned by MPHL outside the firm.

decision.conclusion:
Appeal dismissed. The accounts were not drawn up in accordance with GAAP; no goodwill should have been recognised for the purposes of the claimed deductions and group relief.
Applying FRS 5.14, the Tribunal concluded that the business operations passed to MCP and that MPHL did not acquire or retain control over the business and was not entitled to recognise goodwill in its accounts.
MPHL did not retain significant benefits or risks under FRS 5.25 and did not control the proceeds of any future sale or profits arising from the business; control over profit allocation and sale proceeds lay with SM as Managing Partner of MCP. Recognition or continued recognition of goodwill in MPHL’s accounts is not supported by FRS 5.25.
The Tribunal rejected the submission that MPL acted as MPHL’s agent, found that the operations of MPL passed to MCP, and determined that MPHL did not retain significant benefits or risks within the meaning of FRS 5.25.
The appellants’ submissions on goodwill were rejected and HMRC’s submissions accepted. Legal goodwill of the MCP business is inseparable from the business and belongs to the partnership (MCP), not MPHL; there was no evidence of any monetary value of legal goodwill.
Appeals dismissed. MPHL did not acquire control over the Milton Park care home business after formation of MCP and was not entitled to recognise purchased goodwill under UK GAAP; HMRC’s alternative derecognition argument was not considered.
The Tribunal rejects the Appellants’ case that MPHL owned the partnership’s legal goodwill or had a proprietary entitlement to its sale proceeds. Clause 9.1 does not confer a right to sale proceeds, and clause 14.2.1 creates only a contingent debt on dissolution. The presumption that goodwill belongs to the partnership is not rebutted on the facts.
decision.reasoning_summary:
Because MPHL’s accounts were not GAAP-compliant as regards recognition of goodwill, no amortisation or impairment debits were allowable and MPL was not entitled to group relief based on such debits; the agreed alternative valuation and consequential relief did not arise.
The commercial substance, assessed as a whole, showed MCP and its Managing Partner controlled operations and profits, evidenced by the MCP Deed and MCP’s accounting records, whereas MPHL’s role was a holding company with no trading income; legal wording reserving goodwill to MPHL could not override GAAP’s control analysis.
Based on the MCP Deed clauses allocating power to SM, witness evidence, meeting minutes, and GAAP/FRS 5 principles, the Tribunal determined that MPHL’s cited rights were contingent or discretionary and did not amount to practical control over the business’s economic benefits.
No documentary or accounting evidence of agency; MPL had full autonomy; relationship better characterised as parent–subsidiary; even if agency existed, MPHL lacked GAAP control per FRS 5.8. Under FRS 5.25, MPHL’s rights were contingent and not significant in practice, particularly given MCP’s governance and the Managing Partner’s discretion over profit allocations.
Legal goodwill attaches to and is owned by the business/partnership; deed provisions cannot alter that legal position, and no valuation evidence was provided to give legal goodwill any demonstrated monetary value.
Goodwill presumptions were not displaced by the MCP Deed’s terms; control under FRS 5.8 requires the power to direct financial and operating policies to obtain economic benefits, which resided with MCP and its Managing Partner SM, not MPHL. Termination or withdrawal rights and de facto personal influence did not constitute control.
Authorities and contractual construction support HMRC’s interpretation: goodwill attaches to the business; clause 9.1 is a declaration of ownership of legal goodwill, not of sale proceeds; clause 14.2.1’s use of “accrue” denotes a debt arising on dissolution; and the Deed’s amendability and lack of consideration to MPHL negate any proprietary entitlement. The general presumption that goodwill is a partnership asset stands on these facts.
